title: 108_s501
content: The "Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003" establishes a grant program for gifted and talented students under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. This program authorizes activities to support gifted and talented students. Congress finds that gifted and talented students demonstrate high performance in various academic fields and require specialized services not typically offered by schools to fully develop their capabilities. These students come from diverse backgrounds, including those with disabilities or non-English speaking backgrounds, who have historically been underrepresented. Elementary and secondary school teachers have students with diverse backgrounds, including disabilities and non-English speaking students, who are historically underrepresented in gifted education programs. Gifted elementary students have already mastered a significant portion of the school year's material before it begins. Elementary and secondary school teachers receive training to meet the needs of students with disabilities, limited English proficiency, and diverse backgrounds, but often lack training for gifted and talented students. Gifted education programs are essential for high-ability students, especially those from inner cities, rural communities, or low-income families, who rely on public schools for services. Teachers often lack training to meet the needs of gifted and talented students from diverse backgrounds. Gifted education programs in public schools are crucial for providing equal opportunities to high-ability students from various backgrounds. Parents and families play a vital role in partnering with schools to support the educational and social-emotional needs of gifted children. They require access to information, research, and resources to help develop appropriate services for these students. Gifted and talented students require access to information, research, and support for their educational, social, and emotional needs. There is no Federal requirement to identify or serve the approximately 3,000,000 gifted students in the nation. While some States allocate resources for gifted education, others do not, leading to disparities in services. To address the disparities in services for gifted and talented students, it is crucial for more students to achieve higher levels of education. This will help meet the future economic and national security needs of the United States. To ensure future economic and national security needs, more students must achieve higher levels of education. Highly capable students should be prepared for innovative and creative work to secure the nation's position globally. The performance of twelfth-grade advanced students in the US on TIMSS was among the lowest worldwide in physics and mathematics content areas. The United States performed poorly in the Third International Mathematics and Science Study (TIMSS), ranking among the lowest in physics and advanced mathematics. In 1990, very little funding was allocated for challenging programs for gifted students in elementary and secondary education. In 1990, minimal funding was allocated for challenging programs for gifted students in elementary and secondary education in the United States. To be eligible for a grant under this chapter, a State educational agency must submit an application to the Secretary with assurances that funds will be used to support gifted and talented students from diverse backgrounds, including those with limited English proficiency and disabilities. The funds received under this chapter must be used to supplement, not replace, state and local funds for the education and services of gifted and talented students from various backgrounds, including those with limited English proficiency and disabilities. Any funds not retained by the State educational agency will be granted to local educational agencies on a competitive basis. The State educational agency must use funds received under this chapter to supplement, not replace, state and local funds for the education of gifted and talented students. The agency must provide matching funds of at least 10 percent of the grant funds and develop program assessment models. The State educational agency must provide matching funds of at least 10 percent of the grant funds, in cash or in kind, and develop program assessment models for accountability and effectiveness. The Secretary will approve a State's application if it meets the requirements of this section. "SEC. 5467C. DISTRIBUTION TO LOCAL EDUCATIONAL AGENCIES." A State educational agency must allocate at least 90 percent of the funds to local educational agencies for grants through a competitive process ensuring equitable distribution within the State based on geographic areas. Local educational agencies receive funds through a competitive process for equitable distribution by geographic area within the State. State educational agencies award grants based on student needs. SEC. 5467D pertains to local applications. To be eligible for a grant under this chapter, a local educational agency must submit an application to the State educational agency. The application must include an assurance that funds will be used to support gifted and talented students from diverse backgrounds, including those with limited English proficiency and disabilities. The local educational agency must describe how they will support gifted and talented students, including training personnel, and ensure that funds are used to supplement, not replace, existing education funds. The local educational agency must ensure that funds received for gifted and talented students will supplement existing education funds, not replace them. The State educational agency must submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing the number of students served and activities supported with funds under the Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003. The report should also include measures taken to comply with specific sections. SEC. 5467F states that recipients of funds under this chapter can serve gifted and talented students alongside those with similar educational needs. SEC. 5467G ensures equitable participation of private school students and teachers in grants, including professional development programs. SEC. 5467H provides definitions. The term 'gifted and talented' in this chapter refers to individuals or programs as defined by applicable State law or by the State educational agency or local educational agency if no State law exists. The term 'gifted and talented' is defined by State law or by the State educational agency if no State law exists. If not defined, it is given the meaning in section 9101. The term 'State' includes the 50 States, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico.
